facts: The five gold pieces given to Pinocchio by Fire-Eater for his father are buried in the Field of Miracles following the Fox's instructions, rather than being delivered to Geppetto.
corrupted_facts: The five gold pieces given to Pinocchio by Fire-Eater for his father are spent on food and entertainment, rather than being delivered to Geppetto.
fact_reasoning: In Chapter 11, Fire-Eater gives Pinocchio five gold pieces to take to his father Geppetto. However, in Chapter 12, Pinocchio is persuaded by the Fox and Cat to go to the Field of Miracles to multiply his money. Finally, in Chapter 18, Pinocchio buries the gold coins in the Field of Miracles as instructed by the Fox. This sequence of events shows how Pinocchio misuses the gift intended for his father.
corrupted_reasoning: The corrupted fact incorrectly states that Pinocchio spends the gold pieces on food and entertainment, when in fact he buries them in the Field of Miracles.

facts: Geppetto builds a boat to search for Pinocchio in the New World, but is swallowed by a Dog-Fish where he survives for two years using supplies from a swallowed merchant vessel.
corrupted_facts: Geppetto builds a boat to search for Pinocchio in the New World, but is swallowed by a Whale where he survives for one year using supplies from his own boat.
fact_reasoning: In Chapter 23, a Pigeon informs Pinocchio that Geppetto is building a boat to search for him in the New World. Later in the same chapter, Pinocchio spots Geppetto in a small boat in the tempestuous sea. In Chapter 35, Geppetto explains that he survived for two years inside the Dog-Fish using supplies from a swallowed merchant vessel. This sequence of events shows Geppetto's journey from building the boat to being swallowed by the Dog-Fish and his subsequent survival.
corrupted_reasoning: The corrupted fact incorrectly states that Geppetto is swallowed by a Whale instead of a Dog-Fish, and that he survives for one year using supplies from his own boat, rather than two years using supplies from a swallowed merchant vessel.

facts: Pinocchio's wooden feet, which he uses to kick Geppetto on the nose after being carved, later catch fire and burn to cinders, prompting Geppetto to make him new feet after Pinocchio promises to be good.
corrupted_facts: Pinocchio's wooden feet, which he uses to kick Geppetto on the nose after being carved, later catch fire and burn to cinders, prompting Pinocchio to make himself new feet after he promises to be good.
fact_reasoning: In Chapter 3, Pinocchio uses his newly carved feet to kick Geppetto on the nose. In Chapter 6, these same wooden feet catch fire and burn to cinders while Pinocchio sleeps. Finally, in Chapter 7, after Pinocchio promises to be good and go to school, Geppetto makes him new feet in less than an hour. This sequence of events shows the transformation of Pinocchio's feet and the consequences of his actions.
corrupted_reasoning: The corrupted fact incorrectly states that Pinocchio makes himself new feet, when it is actually Geppetto who makes the new feet for Pinocchio.
